title: What are some mind-blowing facts about human philosophy? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think the scope and limits of human minds is one of the most interesting questions those minds can ask. What questions are simply beyond the human capacity to even ask? What kinds of things would only advanced aliens know? What would they sound like to us? Would it be like trying to teach chimps philosophy? Is the universe far more sophisticated than our puny minds can ever comprehend? Basic matter turns out to be virtually incomprehensible. We can’t even finish writing the maths of atoms. We’ve made heroic headway, made a quantum-theoretic account of the chemical bond uniting chemistry and physics in the 1930s, figured out relativity and measured gravitational waves. But we still don’t even understand what gravity is. “Forces” are inherently mysterious, why we use the same word for what Luke Skywalker uses and what holds a planet together. Understanding of things like consciousness appears to be firmly within the realm of mysticism and outside the realm of science. In other words the human mind does not appear to be capable of scientifically approaching basic questions about itself like How am I a conscious? And that is one of the most interesting facts about human philosophy to me.  Amazon.com: The End Of Science: Facing The Limits Of Knowledge In The Twilight Of The Scientific Age (9780465065929): John Horgan: Books For an intro to the topic of the limits of human cognition. chomsky newton - Google Search For the grad-level crash course in the topic (Chomsky believes Newton first discovered cognitive science by discovering gravity and refusing to believe in it because it’s “absurd.”) the mysterious flame - Google Search For a book-length treatment of the concept of consciousness which admits that we don’t have a clue what it is (if you accept that religious conceptions are really just metaphors and not scientific understanding).
